race.name: Traka 360
race.tagline: Europe's answer to Unbound—born in Girona, the pro cycling mecca
race.race_challenge_tagline: 23,000 feet of climbing on technical Mediterranean terrain

climate.description: 18-28°C (65-82°F) with variable spring weather. Morning cold, afternoon heat, possible mountain rain.

terrain.primary: Rocky Mediterranean gravel with technical sections
terrain.surface: Mediterranean gravel—loose rocks, forest singletrack, technical descents that punish tired legs

altitude.altitude_impact: MODERATE - Tops out ~1,400m (4,600 ft). Not high enough to significantly impact oxygen. Volume of climbing, not altitude of climbing.

history.origin_story: Born in Girona—where WorldTour pros live and train. Exploded from grassroots to Europe's largest gravel event in four years. The race that proved European gravel could match American ambition.
notable_moments: Equal prize purse men/women from inception
history.reputation: Europe's Unbound. If Unbound is America's gravel Ironman, Traka is Europe's. The field draws WorldTour crossover athletes and weekend warriors alike.
random_facts: Girona is where Tadej Pogačar and other WorldTour pros train
The course literally rides through pro cycling's spiritual home
4,000+ riders from 74 countries creates genuine international field
Night racing through Pyrenean foothills is mandatory for 360km
UCI World Series status brings legitimacy and points

course_description.character: Relentless climbing on Mediterranean gravel. Not one killer climb—7,000 meters of accumulated suffering spread across 360km.

suffering_zones.label: First Mountain Pass
suffering_zones.desc: The opening act. Legs still fresh, ego intact. You think you've got this.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: First real test of climbing fitness

suffering_zones.label: Halfway Reality
suffering_zones.desc: The climbing doesn't stop. Your legs know exactly what's coming for the next 180km.

suffering_zones.label: Night Falls
suffering_zones.desc: Headlamps on. The final 60km in darkness. Technical terrain on empty legs.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Technical descents on fried legs separate finishers from DNFs

course_description.signature_challenge: 23,000 feet of climbing on technical Mediterranean terrain. The pro cycling training ground becomes YOUR proving ground.

prestige.explanation: Europe's Unbound. 74 countries. WorldTour crossover athletes. UCI World Series. The race that proved European gravel could match American ambition.

length.explanation: 360km = 16-24 hours. You'll see sunset AND sunrise. This is ultra-endurance territory disguised as a gravel race.

technicality.explanation: Mediterranean rock isn't forgiving. Technical descents on fried legs separate finishers from DNFs. Forest singletrack sections demand bike handling when you're most fatigued.

elevation.explanation: 7,000m of climbing. Not one epic climb—dozens of punchy efforts that never let you recover. The cumulative fatigue is relentless.

climate.explanation: May in Catalonia is generally mild. Pack layers, but it's not Unbound heat or Reiver cold. Variable spring weather requires flexibility.

altitude.explanation: Tops out ~1,400m. Not high enough to significantly impact oxygen. Volume of climbing, not altitude of climbing.

adventure.explanation: Girona is cycling's spiritual home. Riding trails where Pogačar trains. Night racing through Pyrenean foothills. This is bucket-list terrain with pro cycling credibility.

logistics.explanation: Barcelona (BCN) 100km or Girona (GRO) 12km. Book 6+ months early. Race week is chaos. €100-200/night. Consider Barcelona + train for better availability.

race_quality.explanation: UCI World Series production value. Equal prize purse from day one. Professional organization that matches the field's international scope.

experience.explanation: You'll remember riding through Girona at night. The Pyrenean foothills. The international field. This is gravel racing as it should be—ambitious, beautiful, and genuinely challenging.

community.explanation: 74 countries creates genuine international community. WorldTour crossover athletes mix with weekend warriors. The Girona cycling culture permeates everything.

field_depth.explanation: WorldTour crossover athletes regularly compete. The international field brings serious depth. This isn't a regional race—it's a global event.

value.explanation: €80-200 entry is reasonable for a UCI World Series event. Travel costs add up (flights to Spain, accommodation), but the experience justifies the investment.

expenses.explanation: Transatlantic flights, accommodation in Girona (€100-200/night), bike transport. Total easily exceeds $2,000-3,000. This is a destination event.

biased_opinion.summary: If you're serious about gravel and have any connection to European cycling culture, Traka is a must. It's not just a race—it's a pilgrimage to the sport's spiritual home. Where else can you suffer on the same roads that Pogačar trains on?
biased_opinion.quote: Europe's Unbound. Born in cycling's spiritual home. 23,000 feet of climbing. You'll see sunrise and sunset.
strengths: The location: Girona is cycling heaven. The race is the excuse; the destination is the reward.
The international field: 74 countries. This isn't a regional race.
The legitimacy: UCI points, WorldTour crossover athletes, equal prize purse.
The terrain: Pyrenean foothills, Mediterranean gravel, technical descents—proper European challenge
weaknesses: Transatlantic distance: Travel cost and jet lag add complexity for US riders
Crowded early kilometers: 4,000 riders creates bottlenecks
Night racing reality: The 360 almost certainly means riding through darkness
The cost: Total trip easily exceeds $2,000-3,000 with flights and accommodation
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Traka is Europe's Unbound—and arguably more technical. If European gravel is on your bucket list, this is the defining event.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: Traka will break you in ways Unbound can't. American gravel is rolling and rough. European gravel is climbing and technical. 23,000 feet of elevation gain on rocky terrain requires a different kind of fitness—and a different kind of suffering tolerance.
consequences: You'll spend $2,000-3,000 minimum (flights, entry, lodging, bike transport)
You'll ride through the night. 16-24 hours means darkness is mandatory
The technical descents after 15+ hours test skills you don't have when exhausted
Jet lag compounds fatigue. Arriving from the US means you're racing on compromised recovery
The climbing never stops. Not one epic climb—dozens of efforts that accumulate into 7,000 meters
black_pill.quote: Train for climbing. Then train for more climbing. Your FTP matters less than your ability to repeat threshold efforts for 20 hours.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This is a mountainous ultra-endurance event disguised as a gravel race. Train for climbing. Then train for more climbing. Your FTP matters less than your ability to repeat threshold efforts for 20 hours.

tldr.should_race_if: You want Europe's premier gravel event, you can handle 16-24 hours of racing, and you're ready for technical terrain on exhausted legs.
tldr.skip_if: You need guaranteed good weather, you can't handle night racing, or you're looking for smooth, fast gravel without technical challenges.

final_verdict.one_liner: Europe's Unbound where 23,000 feet of climbing meets technical Mediterranean terrain in cycling's spiritual home.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes, if you want Europe's premier gravel event and can handle 16-24 hours of racing. Traka delivers international credibility, stunning Pyrenean terrain, and a genuine challenge that matches its reputation. Just be ready for night racing and relentless climbing.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want European gravel without the ultra distance: Dirty Reiver (UK, 210km). If you want bucket-list adventure: The Rift (Iceland, volcanic terrain). If you want American ultra: Unbound 200 (Kansas, heat challenge).

logistics.lodging_strategy: Book 6+ months early. Race week is chaos. €100-200/night. Consider Barcelona + train for better availability and lower prices.
logistics.food: Girona has excellent restaurants. Catalan cuisine is world-class. Book reservations early—race week fills up.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday in Girona. Expo atmosphere, budget 90 minutes. International field means crowds.
logistics.parking: Limited. Public transport or hotel shuttles recommended. Girona is walkable.

seo.title: Traka 360 Race Guide | Training Plans & Girona Course Intel
seo.meta_description: Traka 360 Girona guide: 224-mile Spanish gravel race. Europe's Unbound with 23,000 feet of climbing on technical Mediterranean terrain. Get training plans & course breakdown.
